metadata.case_name: M/s. Crown Aluminium Works, Belur represented by Jeewanlal (1929) Ltd. v. Workmen represented by Bengal Aluminium Workers Union

facts.text: In 1947, first Omnibus Engineering Tribunal constituted for engineering industry in West Bengal, including disputes on basic wages, dearness allowance and leave; award published June 30, 1948; appellant bound by it.

Industrial disputes arose again; second tribunal award published September 21, 1950, increasing dearness allowance due to rise in cost of living and modifying leave rules per Factories Act, 1948; appellant not party as no dispute raised.
Appellant revised facility bonus from time to time to keep pace with cost of living; no grievance by workmen on dearness allowance.

Minor dispute referred to Shri G. Palit on November 24, 1950, including increment for 1950; appellant denied liability claiming handsome remuneration via special allowance, bonus, dearness allowance; Palit allowed 1 anna per day increment, directed arrears payment, cautioned for fixed wage structure.

Appellant issued notice March 28, 1952, proposing reduction of hours from 47 to 40, facility bonus by 3 as. per day, temporary dearness allowance by 10%; effective June 1, 1952, due to financial setback.
Further notice May 30, 1952: further facility bonus reduction by 6 as., withdraw two hours concession, discharge rolling mills workers.
Union agreed only to hours reduction to 42-1/2; joint discussions June 2 and 26, 1952 failed.
Company notice June 27, 1952: implemented March 28 reductions from June 1, withdraw two hours from July 1, discharge rolling mills from August 1.
Dispute to Labour Commissioner; conference July 4, 1952 failed.
Appellant discharged 52 rolling mills workers July 15, 1952, retrenched 227 others from July 26, 1952, with notice pay.
Government referred 13 matters to Sixth Industrial Tribunal (Shri S.K. Niyogi) on July 31, 1952 under s.10 Industrial Disputes Act.
Sixth Tribunal award October 9, 1953: revised wage structure per 1948/1950 awards, held two hours concession, facility bonus, food concession as bounty withdrawable; allowed abolition post-revision.

Cross-appeals to Labour Appellate Tribunal; disposed July 11/29, 1955: modified wage structure, incorporated concessions into basic wages/dearness allowance for existing workmen; no reduction of existing emoluments.

Appellant took over unit August 9, 1951; manufactures aluminium utensils from imported circles; rolling mills started during war for scrap, closed February 1952 due to losses as better circles available.
Financials 1947-Sept 1952: sales fall, manufacturing cost > sale price in 1952; original tribunal no improvement prospect, Appellate saw improvement post-retrenchment.
Two hours concession introduced August 1946 to compensate post-Factories Act hour reduction; facility bonus April 1945 revised upward to 6-12 as./day; food concession pre-1951.
Appellant's Labour Officer Shah: facility bonus for high cost of living like DA; two hours as special bonus on demand when possible.
Appellant's pleading: pre-June 1952 wage structure had basic wage, DA, special bonus, facility bonus, food concession.

legal_issues.text: Whether there is a convention in industrial adjudication not to reduce existing emoluments/wage structure to prejudice of workmen, and if wage structure can be revised downward if employer's finances deteriorate.
True character of two hours concession, facility bonus, food concession: bounty or integral part of wage structure.

petitioner_arguments.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal erred in assuming convention against reducing emoluments to workmen's prejudice; wage structure revisable downward like upward for financial deterioration/other factors.
Concessional payments (two hours, facility bonus, food) are bounty, withdrawable; Shri Palit held so.
Financial losses justify reductions; post-retrenchment improvement insufficient.

respondent_arguments.text: Concessional payments enjoyed long as of right, part of basic wages/DA, terms of service; convention against reduction.

court_reasoning.text: Industrial adjudication aims social/economic justice, harmony; considers comparable wages, productivity, cost of living, ability to pay; categories: living/fair/minimum wage.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No industry right to exist below bare minimum wage.

court_reasoning.text: Wage structure revisable to prejudice workmen if above minimum and merits shown (e.g., finances, duration of hardship, retrenchment adequacy); no rigid convention, but balance discontent vs. industry survival.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Answer in abstract favors employer, subject to considerations.

court_reasoning.text: Appellate Tribunal considered finances, retrenchment improvement, cost of living data insufficiency; wages at minimum/fair level; decision not vitiated.
Payments not bounty: introduced to compensate, revised with cost of living, pleaded as wage structure components, no dispute raised due to them; part of basic/DA.

holdings.text: Wage structure can be revised downward to prejudice workmen if above bare minimum wage and case made on merits, considering finances, retrenchment, etc.; no inexorable convention against.
Appellate Tribunal's wage structure modification and incorporation of concessions valid, based on evidence/facts.
Two hours concession, facility bonus, food concession form part of basic wages/dearness allowance.

statutes_cited.name: Factories Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Modified leave rules; reduced working hours leading to concessions

statutes_cited.name: Minimum Wages Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Labour welfare legislation enabling wage fixation

outcome.summary: Both contentions of appellant fail; Appellate Tribunal's wage structure upheld, including integration of concessional payments for existing workmen; no interference warranted.

key_quotes.text: "No industry has a right to exist unless it is able to pay its workmen at least a bare minimum wage."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Can the wage structure fixed in a given industry be never revised to the prejudice of its workmen? Considered as a general question in the abstract it must be answered in favour of Mr. Sen."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "It would not be right to hold that there is a rigid and inexorable convention that the wage structure once fixed by industrial tribunals can never be changed to the prejudice of workmen."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key holding on flexibility of wage structures
